verses.text: When Ehud died, the people of Israel again did what was evil in the sight of the LORD.
verses.comment: As in previous cycles, Israel returns to sin after the judge dies, showing their dependence on spiritual leadership and hinting at the need for a lasting deliverer.

verses.text: So the LORD sold them into the hand of Jabin, king of Canaan, who reigned in Hazor. His army commander was Sisera, who lived in Harosheth-haggoyim.
verses.comment: The language 'sold them' shows God's sovereignty even in judgment. Hazor was a major city, and Sisera's role as an outsider is significant.

verses.text: The people of Israel cried out to the LORD, for Jabin had nine hundred iron chariots and severely oppressed the Israelites for twenty years.
verses.comment: Iron chariots represent overwhelming military power. The oppression's duration again highlights the necessity of divine intervention.

verses.text: Deborah, a prophetess, the wife of Lappidoth, was judging Israel at that time.
verses.comment: Deborah's prophetic and judicial roles show God's use of women in leadership and as vessels for his word (see also Acts 2:17).

verses.text: She used to sit under the Palm of Deborah between Ramah and Bethel in the hill country of Ephraim, and the Israelites came to her for judgment.
verses.comment: This verse points to Deborah’s public and revered position; people sought her out, much like later bishops and spiritual leaders are approached for wisdom.

verses.text: She sent for Barak son of Abinoam from Kedesh in Naphtali and said to him, 'Has not the LORD, the God of Israel, commanded: “Go, gather your men at Mount Tabor, taking ten thousand from Naphtali and Zebulun”?'
verses.comment: God’s calling is delivered through Deborah, showing the importance of mediation in God's instructions much like the role of spiritual authorities.

verses.text: 'I will draw out Sisera, the commander of Jabin’s army, with his chariots and his multitude to the river Kishon, and I will give him into your hand.'
verses.comment: God promises victory, emphasizing the divine initiative and foreknowledge, which anticipates Christ's ultimate victory over evil.

verses.text: Barak said to her, 'If you will go with me, I will go; but if you will not go with me, I will not go.'
verses.comment: Barak's dependence on Deborah’s presence highlights the value of wise, divinely-inspired leadership. Spiritual guidance is essential for success.

verses.text: She replied, 'I will surely go with you. Nevertheless, the journey you are taking will not bring you honor, for the LORD will sell Sisera into the hand of a woman.' Then Deborah arose and went with Barak to Kedesh.
verses.comment: This hints at God's tendency to choose the humble and unexpected tools for His plans, echoing Mary's role in salvation history and the reversal of worldly expectations.

verses.text: Barak called Zebulun and Naphtali to Kedesh, and ten thousand men went up at his command, and Deborah went with him.
verses.comment: Barak's obedience and Deborah’s accompaniment signal the importance of unity and collaboration in the service to God’s plan.

verses.text: Now Heber the Kenite had separated himself from the other Kenites, the descendants of Hobab, Moses' father-in-law, and had pitched his tent by the oak at Zaanannim, near Kedesh.
verses.comment: Heber’s separation foreshadows his unique role in the coming events, showing God’s use of diverse individuals across salvation history.

verses.text: When Sisera was told that Barak son of Abinoam had gone up to Mount Tabor,
verses.comment: Sisera’s awareness of Barak’s movement sets the stage for his confrontation and ultimate defeat.

verses.text: Sisera called out all his chariots, nine hundred iron chariots, and all the men who were with him, from Harosheth-haggoyim to the river Kishon.
verses.comment: The assembling of chariots recalls Pharaoh’s army and amplifies the coming miracle, reminding us of God’s power over human strength.

verses.text: Deborah said to Barak, 'Rise up! For this is the day in which the LORD has handed Sisera over to you. Has not the LORD gone out before you?' So Barak went down from Mount Tabor with ten thousand men following him.
verses.comment: Deborah’s prophetic authority assures God will act, echoing the assurance of God’s real presence and intervention for His people.

verses.text: The LORD threw Sisera and all his chariots and all his army into confusion before Barak; Sisera got down from his chariot and fled away on foot.
verses.comment: God directly intervenes, reminiscent of other biblical battles where confusion leads to victory (see 1 Sam 7:10).

verses.text: Barak pursued the chariots and the army all the way to Harosheth-haggoyim, and all Sisera's army fell by the sword; not one man was left.
verses.comment: The totality of the victory points to both immediate deliverance and a foreshadowing of Christ's complete triumph over sin and death.

verses.text: But Sisera fled on foot to the tent of Jael, the wife of Heber the Kenite, for there was peace between Jabin king of Hazor and the house of Heber the Kenite.
verses.comment: Sisera’s flight to Jael’s tent introduces the pivotal role of Jael and shows how God uses unexpected individuals to execute His plans.

verses.text: Jael went out to meet Sisera and said to him, 'Turn aside, my lord, turn aside to me; do not be afraid.' So he turned aside to her into the tent, and she covered him with a blanket.
verses.comment: Jael’s hospitality masks her decisive role; the blanket foreshadows her actions and also echoes biblical themes, like protection and sanctuary.

verses.text: He said to her, 'Please give me a little water to drink, for I am thirsty.' So she opened a skin of milk, gave him a drink, and covered him.
verses.comment: The giving of milk instead of water highlights Jael’s cunning; the gesture calms Sisera, setting up the fulfillment of Deborah's prophecy.

verses.text: He said to her, 'Stand at the entrance of the tent, and if anyone comes and asks you, “Is there a man here?” say, “No.”'
verses.comment: Sisera’s request reveals his desperation; Jael’s silence and actions preview the subversion of expectations.

verses.text: But Jael, Heber’s wife, took a tent peg and a hammer and went softly to him and drove the peg into his temple while he was sleeping. He died there.
verses.comment: Jael's act fulfills Deborah’s prophecy and demonstrates the reversal of human strength by weakness; spiritually, it prefigures triumph through humility.

verses.text: Then, as Barak was pursuing Sisera, Jael went out to meet him and said, 'Come, and I will show you the man you are seeking.' So he went into her tent, and there lay Sisera dead, with the peg in his temple.
verses.comment: Barak witnesses Jael’s victory, and God's word through Deborah is fully confirmed. God’s promises always come to pass, even through unlikely people.

verses.text: So on that day God subdued Jabin king of Canaan before the people of Israel.
verses.comment: Victory is credited to God, underscoring divine providence. Human instruments fulfill God's will, much like saints and holy men and women in all ages.

verses.text: And the hand of the Israelites pressed harder and harder against Jabin king of Canaan, until they destroyed Jabin king of Canaan.
verses.comment: The gradual strengthening of Israel is analogous to growing in grace through persistent faithfulness, reminding us of the importance of perseverance in holy living.
